You should now see the New Account Properties dialog:



Select a username for the new account you're creating and type it into the Username field.

Note:The username must be at least 4 characters long.

Write down the username you've selected. You're going to need it later.

TIP: For the purposes of this tutorial, you can select a username such as user_guy and a password such as 12345. These are not secure, but will serve for demo purposes.

Select a password for the new account you're creating and type it into the Password field.

Note:The password must be at least 4 characters long.

Write down the password you've selected. You're going to need it later.
For verification, type the password again into the Repeat Password field.

text.text: Click "OK" button to create a new account.

html.body: Wait while the dialog is shown...

text.text: The server is creating new user account...

html.body:
• Locate the Users node in the System Tree and right-click it.
  • In the context menu, locate New User Account:




  • Click it.

text.text: Wait while the dialog pops up...

html.body:
You should now see the User Properties dialog. This dialog allows you to configure both user data and user permissions. For now, we will just enter some sample data:

  • Enter a First Name (e.g "John").
  • Enter a Last Name (e.g "Doe").
  • Enter an address -- several fields have been provided for that, including Country, State, Zip Code etc.
  • Enter a phone number.
  • Now click OK to save the new user data.

Note: The other tab of this dialog contains the Permissions Table for this user. $R{productServer} features a robust and highly-configurable permissions system, and this is your first glance at it. For now, leave the default settings as they are.

You have just created your first User Account - well done!

Now let's configure this account and fill in some details about the new user:

  • Look in the System Tree and find the Users node. Click the to expand it.
  • Find the new user account you have created. Right-click it to show its context menu.
  • In the context menu, locate Edit User Properties:




  • Click it.

$R{product} is a multi-user system. Currently, you are logged on as an Administrator. The routine operation of the system is done by Users, who have less privileges than Administrators.

Before adding any actual Device Servers to your configuration, we are going to create a User Account. We will then add Device Servers for this User (in another tutorial).

To begin, click Next.

You have now configured a new user account, as well as edited some of its related data. Well done!

The next thing is to add some Device Servers this user could interact with. To do this, please click to begin the next tutorial, Connect a Data Terminal.
